items.title: 'Use your nose': Health warnings as winds push Victorian bushfire smoke north
items.description: Health experts and authorities are urging people living north of Victoria's bushfires to limit their time outdoors as a weather system pushes bushfire smoke across the state and into New South Wales.

items.title: Volunteer firefighter's home burns while he battles Victorian bushfires
items.description: CFA volunteer Michael Harper discovers through the truck radio while on shift that his home is under threat.

items.title: Thousands protest against ICE after fatal shooting of Renee Nicole Good
items.description: The protests come after Renee Nicole Good was fatally shot by an immigration officer in Minneapolis.

items.title: Live: Nearly 22,000 homes without power after ex-Cyclone Koji crosses coast
items.description: Ex-Tropical Cyclone Koji makes landfall in north Queensland as a tropical low, bringing heavy rain and damaging winds. Follow live.

items.title: US strikes over 35 ISIS sites in Syria with 90+ munitions

featured_image.name: US carries out additional 'large-scale' strikes on ISIS targets in Syria

items.description:
The United States and allied forces conducted extensive airstrikes against Islamic State targets across Syria on Saturday afternoon, firing more than 90 precision munitions at over 35 locations in the second major wave of a sustained military campaign to retaliate for the killing of three Americans last month[1][2][3][4][5].

The strikes, carried out at approximately 12:30 p.m. Eastern Time, involved more than 20 aircraft including F-15E Strike Eagles, A-10 Warthogs, AC-130J gunships, MQ-9 Reaper drones, and Jordanian F-16s, according to U.S. Central Command[1][4]. The military operation is part of Operation Hawkeye Strike, authorized by President Donald Trump on December 19 in response to a deadly ISIS ambush near Palmyra that killed two Iowa National Guard soldiers and a U.S. civilian interpreter on December 13[1][2][3][5].

items.title: Iran Guards call security a 'red line' amid 13th day of protests

featured_image.name: Iran's Guards Declare 'Red Line' on Security as Tehran Seeks ...

items.description:
Iran's Revolutionary Guards declared Saturday that safeguarding security is a "red line" as authorities escalated efforts to crush the largest anti-government protests in years, now entering their 13th consecutive day amid a nationwide internet blackout and mounting international pressure.

The warning from the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, broadcast on state television, came as protests that began over soaring inflation on December 28 have evolved into calls for an end to clerical rule[1][2][3]. The elite force accused "terrorists" of targeting military and law enforcement bases and said continued unrest was "unacceptable"[1][4].

items.title: Venezuela frees 18 political prisoners after Maduro capture

featured_image.name: Venezuela releases imprisoned opposition figures, which ...

items.description:
Venezuela has released 18 political prisoners as of Saturday morning, following the U.S. military capture of President Nicolás Maduro one week earlier[1][2]. The prisoner releases mark the first concessions by Venezuela's interim government since U.S. forces seized Maduro in a raid on Caracas on January 3[3][4][5].

President Donald Trump announced Friday that he had canceled a planned "second wave of attacks" on Venezuela after the country began freeing detainees[3][6][7]. "Venezuela is releasing large numbers of political prisoners as a sign of 'Seeking Peace,'" Trump wrote on Truth Social, calling it "a very important and smart gesture"[3][8][7]. Trump said the U.S. and Venezuela "are working well together, especially as it pertains to rebuilding, in a much bigger, better, and more modern form, their oil and gas infrastructure"[3][7].

Jorge Rodríguez, president of Venezuela's National Assembly and brother of interim president Delcy Rodríguez, announced Thursday that a "significant number" of prisoners would be released immediately as a gesture to promote "peaceful coexistence"[3][5][9]. He did not specify how many would be freed or provide names[3][4][5].

items.title: The ABC was allowed in to Afghanistan. This is what we saw
items.description: Four years after the Taliban's return to power, security is no longer the defining issue in Afghanistan. Instead, one of the world's worst humanitarian crises is exacerbated by a series of overlapping disasters.

items.title: Six dead, including child, in Mississippi shootings, suspect charged
items.description: A man is charged with murder after six people from the same family were killed in a series of shootings.

items.title: Astronomers reveal 'ghost galaxy' and platypus galaxies

featured_image.name: NASA's Hubble Examines Cloud-9, First of New Type of Object ...

items.description:
Astronomers presented two groundbreaking discoveries this week at the 247th meeting of the American Astronomical Society in Phoenix, unveiling celestial objects that challenge prevailing theories about how galaxies form and evolve.

Using NASA's Hubble Space Telescope, researchers confirmed the first-ever detection of a starless dark matter cloud dubbed Cloud-9, located 14 million light-years from Earth near the spiral galaxy Messier 94[1][2][3][4][5][6]. The object represents a category called Reionization-Limited H I Clouds, or RELHICs—theoretical "failed galaxies" that never accumulated enough gas to ignite star formation[1][2][3][7][8][9].

"This is a tale of a failed galaxy," said Alejandro Benitez-Llambay, an astrophysicist at the University of Milano-Bicocca in Milan, Italy, who serves as the study's principal investigator[1][10][11]. The findings, published in The Astrophysical Journal Letters in November 2025, were presented Monday at the conference[1][8][11].

Cloud-9's core spans roughly 4,900 light-years and contains about one million solar masses of neutral hydrogen gas[1][3][8]. Yet calculations suggest the cloud sits within a dark matter halo weighing approximately five billion solar masses—mass that provides gravitational structure without producing visible light[1][3][12].

"Cloud-9 gives us a rare look at a dark-matter-dominated cloud," said Andrew Fox, an astronomer at the Space Telescope Science Institute for the European Space Agency[1][3][13].

The discovery began three years ago when China's Five-hundred-meter Aperture Spherical Telescope detected the hydrogen cloud during a radio survey[1][2][3][4][14][15]. Subsequent observations from the Green Bank Telescope and Very Large Array confirmed the gas presence, but only Hubble's Advanced Camera for Surveys could definitively rule out stars[1][3][4][8][13].

"Before we used Hubble, you could argue that this is a faint dwarf galaxy that we could not see with ground-based telescopes," said lead author Gagandeep Anand of the Space Telescope Science Institute[3][13][12]. "But with Hubble's Advanced Camera for Surveys, we're able to nail down that there's nothing there."

items.description: Authorities are continuing to battle out-of-control bushfires across Victoria, which have already claimed dozens of properties. Meanwhile, extreme heatwave warnings remain in place for NSW, ACT and WA. Follow live.

items.title: Greenland parliament unites to reject Trump acquisition threats

featured_image.name: Greenland's Democrats want broad coalition to show unity in face of Trump pressure

items.description:
President Donald Trump intensified his push to acquire Greenland on Friday, declaring the United States will "do something on Greenland whether they like it or not," as the world's largest island becomes a flashpoint for geopolitical tensions over its vast mineral wealth and strategic Arctic position[1][2][3].

All five political parties in Greenland's parliament issued a unified rejection hours later. "We do not want to be Americans, we do not want to be Danes, we want to be Greenlanders," the leaders stated in a rare joint declaration, announcing an expedited parliamentary session to address the escalating U.S. threats[2][4]. The island's 57,000 residents have consistently rejected Trump's overtures, with Prime Minister Jens-Frederik Nielsen reiterating that "Greenland is not for sale"[1][3].

items.title: Richest 1% exhausted 2026 carbon budget in 10 days, Oxfam says

featured_image.name: Richest 1% have 'blown through' their carbon budget for 2026 in just ...

items.description:
The richest 1 percent of the world's population exhausted their annual carbon emissions allowance just 10 days into 2026, according to research released by Oxfam on January 10. The finding underscores growing concerns about climate inequality as governments face mounting pressure to impose wealth taxes and restrict luxury carbon consumption.

Oxfam designated January 10 as "Pollutocrat Day," the date when the wealthiest exceeded safe emission limits needed to keep global warming within 1.5 degrees Celsius above preindustrial levels, as outlined in the Paris Agreement[1]. The analysis, using data from the Stockholm Environment Institute, found the richest 1 percent emit 75.1 tonnes of carbon dioxide per person annually, or 0.206 tonnes daily[1]. In stark contrast, someone from the poorest half of the global population would take nearly three years to use their carbon allowance[2][3].

The ultra-wealthy crossed this threshold even faster. The richest 0.1 percent depleted their annual budget by January 3, just three days into the new year[4][1].

items.title: Indonesia blocks Musk's Grok over deepfake concerns

featured_image.name: No 10 hits out at 'insulting' changes to Musk's Grok chatbot after ...

items.description:
Indonesia on Saturday became the first country to block Elon Musk's Grok chatbot, citing concerns over the AI tool's ability to generate sexually explicit deepfake images of women and children without consent[1][2][3][4].

Communications and Digital Minister Meutya Hafid announced the temporary ban to "protect women, children, and the entire community from the risk of fake pornographic content generated using artificial intelligence technology"[2][3][4]. The minister characterized the practice of non-consensual sexual deepfakes as "a serious violation of human rights, dignity, and the security of citizens in the digital space"[3][4][5], calling it a form of "digital-based violence"[1][6][7].

items.title: Iran cuts internet as protests enter 13th day

featured_image.name: Why are Iranians protesting and what does it mean for the regime?

items.description:
Iran plunged into a nationwide internet blackout on Thursday as anti-government protests entered their thirteenth day, with authorities responding to the most significant unrest since the 2022 "Woman, Life, Freedom" movement[1][2][3]. Human rights groups report at least 42 people have been killed and more than 2,300 arrested since demonstrations erupted across all 31 provinces[4][5][6].

The internet shutdown came after exiled Crown Prince Reza Pahlavi called for coordinated demonstrations at 8 p.m. local time on Thursday and Friday evenings[7][8]. Monitoring organization NetBlocks confirmed connectivity had dropped to 1% of normal levels by Friday, hampering communication and masking the scale of the crackdown[9][10].

items.title: Superheavy rockets could slash space telescope costs

featured_image.name: SpaceX launches 11th test flight of its mega Starship rocket ... - NPR

items.description:
Recent successful launches of SpaceX's Starship and Blue Origin's New Glenn rockets are raising hopes among astronomers that a new generation of more affordable space telescopes could arrive years ahead of schedule, potentially ending a looming gap in space-based observations.

The two superheavy-lift vehicles achieved major milestones in late 2025—Starship's fully successful Flight 11 test on October 13 and New Glenn's second flight on November 13, which deployed NASA's ESCAPADE Mars mission and successfully landed its booster[1][2][3]. These achievements come as NASA faces an expected decade-long wait until 2045 or later for its next flagship observatory, creating what Martin Elvis, a senior astrophysicist at the Smithsonian Institution, calls "a forbidding timeline"[4][5].

items.title: France reschedules G7 summit to avoid Trump UFC party

featured_image.name: UFC White House Update: Dana White Unveils More Details

items.description:
France has postponed this year's Group of Seven summit by one day to prevent a scheduling conflict with a mixed martial arts event at the White House on June 14, which coincides with President Donald Trump's 80th birthday[1][2][3][4].

The annual gathering of world leaders in Evian-les-Bains, originally scheduled for June 14-16, will now take place June 15-17, according to two officials familiar with the G7's arrangements[1][2][5]. The date change was first reported by Politico on Friday and has been updated on the G7's official website[6][3][5].

June 14 marks Flag Day in the United States, Trump's milestone birthday, and the date he announced in October for a "big UFC fight" on the White House grounds as part of the nation's 250th anniversary celebrations[7][8][9]. UFC CEO Dana White confirmed to CBS News this week that preparations are complete, with approximately 5,000 spectators expected on the South Lawn and up to 85,000 more at a public viewing area on the nearby Ellipse[10][11].

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].
